newsitem.title: USA: Albright says U.S. Korea policy "on right track".
newsitem.headline: Albright says U.S. Korea policy "on right track".

text.p: Secretary of State Madeleine Albright said on Friday that the United States was "on the right track" in its dealings with North Korea despite a failure so far to set up four-party talks on the future of Korea.
She told a news conference there had been "some positive reaction" from Pyongyang to a U.S.-South Korean proposal made more than a year ago to hold the discussions, which would also include China.
The talks would be aimed at closing the book on the 1950-53 Korean War, which ended in a now-fraying armistice.

At a meeting in New York last month, North Korea agreed to join such talks if it was first guaranteed large-scale food aid, U.S. diplomatic recognition and an easing of trade sanctions. Washington has made clear that once peace talks start, stepped-up aid is a strong possibility.
Albright admitted that there had been "a delay in finding the time" to stage the negotiations.
But, she added: "I would say that we're very much on the right track and that it's a matter of seeing what the conditions are to make sure that those talks do in fact take place."
The status of the four-party talks was at the centre of a meeting Albright held later with visiting South Korean Foreign Minister Yoo Chong-ha.

South Korea, like the United States, has provided North Korea with small-scale food aid to offset a severe shortage in the isolated Stalinist country, but agrees with Washington that major assistance must await the opening of peace talks.

Albright told reporters the talks would cover the food situation in North Korea as well as implementation of a 1994 agreement under which Pyongyang agreed to freeze its nuclear programme in return for supply of new nuclear reactors.

Despite periodic scares in South Korea that the United States is dealing with North Korea behind Seoul's back, Yoo told reporters his country's relations with Washington had "never been stronger" than now.
Albright and Yoo signed an agreement bringing into force a treaty originally signed between the two countries in 1993 on mutual legal assistance.
U.S. officials said it provided for cooperation in investigations of a wide variety of crimes including drug trafficking and terrorism.
